stream_context.summary: Kaze’s session starts with an abandoned attempt to let two sound-effects per bank play concurrently, then shifts almost entirely to graphics work on a large beach-style level.  Most of the stream is spent iterating on new water tech: shoreline wave-height falloff, vertex-driven foam, and texture-scroll logic, while fielding chat questions about releases, emulators, AI tools, and life philosophy.
level: Beach / shoreline level (course name not given)

development_findings.summary: Kaze is building an audio rewrite that lets two sound effects from the same bank play simultaneously to improve overall SFX quality; he halted live debugging because it was getting too complex and will finish off-stream.
development_findings.quote: Basically what I'm trying to do is make it so that two sound effects per bank can play at the same time. This would seriously improve the sound effect quality across the board.

development_findings.summary: He fully traced the infamous low-pitched 'Booloth' noise: it is baked into the ‘air howling wind’ sample and only audible when the layer loop is interrupted, e.g., by entering the Big Boo door.
development_findings.quote: What's really going on is that the Booloth is just a part of the wind sound effect … usually you don't hear it, but when you cancel the sound effect, you do hear it.

development_findings.summary: Water system overhaul: shoreline vertices now carry a scalar that forces wave height to zero near land, while offshore waves remain large; foam will be a separate clamped texture that scrolls on a sine path and fades with vertex alpha.
development_findings.quote: We got big waves over there and then small waves here … Next, let's make some foam here.

development_findings.summary: Because vertex alpha is already used, he plans to encode wave-height data in the low bits of the vertex red channel to save memory.
development_findings.quote: We could use the lower bits of the red channel for the wave height. I think that might genuinely be our best option.

development_findings.summary: A missing 'material label' export from the Blender plug-in blocks clean display-list insertion; unless Lilaa adds it, Kaze will write a runtime workaround that scans for the first tile-size command after a texture pointer.
development_findings.quote: If we don't get material labels, I'm going to make an init function now that finds the index of the thing I need.

development_findings.summary: Engine progress continues even while content slows; ROM size currently ~59 MB and a single Z-buffer segment now shares space with rarely-read graph nodes to minimise memory impact of decorative models.
development_findings.quote: In the meantime I've been upgrading the engine, so it's not like I've been making too much progress on the content either.

development_findings.summary: In-game analytics already track play time, jumps, deaths, damage, coins, and savestates for post-release stats.
development_findings.quote: We are already capturing the playtime stats: total jump stamps, playtime deaths, damage taken, coins obtained, save states.

development_findings.summary: He refuses to integrate AI tools (e.g., GitHub Copilot) after strong community pushback and sees little benefit for his workflow.
development_findings.quote: People will get really mad at me if I do anything AI, or if anything AI touches this game.

development_findings.summary: Persistent emulator headaches: Project64 1.6 remains his primary dev emulator despite security flaws because alternatives (Ares, Parallel) are "unusable"; he previously fixed an off-by-one memory bug in Parallel that resurfaced after release.
development_findings.quote: On the last RTYI demo release, I worked with Falco to fix the bug … a week later I released my ROM hack and people didn't get the update.

development_findings.summary: Approximately ten collaborators have full repo access and he maintains a private asset backup to ensure the project survives any personal emergency.
development_findings.quote: There's like 10 people that have access to Return to Yoshi's Island. I also have a private repo with all the assets, so nothing would be lost if I died.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a utilitarian view on life’s value, saying the worth lies in what he creates rather than in himself.
context_findings.quote: I myself as a human don't have much value, right? The value's in what I make.

context_findings.summary: He recounts a recent near-attack by three large dogs, highlighting personal vulnerability and mild trauma.
context_findings.quote: I did almost die yesterday … their neighbors had three big dogs that all came running and barking at me.

context_findings.summary: Shows ongoing anxiety about public backlash, especially around AI usage and political discussions, leading him to avoid both topics on stream.
context_findings.quote: Maybe I just shouldn't worry about stuff like that, but it does suck … my new excuse is to say it's all culture war and I won't talk about it.

context_findings.summary: Mentions the couple’s home-search outing with Zeina, indicating shared life outside development.
context_findings.quote: Zayna is sending me pictures. Yes. Look what a nice region we were in. This is like the perfect place to live.

biobak.summary: Provides art direction on water; specifically asked for large offshore waves tapered to flat water near shore and eventual foam overlay.
biobak.quote: I'm assuming I did it wrong. Too bad, that's salt water … This is exactly what Biobak wanted. We got big waves over there and then small waves here.

biobak.summary: Will ultimately replace Kaze’s placeholder textures, so Kaze keeps interim work "semi-decent looking" to avoid making him "puke."
biobak.quote: I'm not trying to put too much work into this, just get this semi-decent looking, so Biobak doesn't puke when he sees this.

zeina.summary: Zeina participated indirectly by sending Kaze photos from their outing, but no production tasks were discussed.

key_stories.title: Solving the Booloth Mystery
key_stories.summary: A decades-old oddity—Big Boo's Hand emitting a low-pitched laugh—was traced live.  Kaze inspected the original sound banks and discovered the boo sample appended to the wind track, only audible when the loop reset is interrupted.
key_stories.challenge: Community confusion over unexplained low-pitch boo noise in Big Boo’s Haunt.
key_stories.process: Opened clean SM64 repo, inspected sample bank 6 instrument 9, identified 299-frame delayed boo segment and explained timing.
key_stories.outcome: Provided definitive technical explanation, closing a long-standing fan debate.
key_stories.key_quote: The Booloth is just a part of the wind sound effect … when you cancel the sound effect, you do hear it.

key_stories.title: Shoreline Water Overhaul
key_stories.summary: Kaze’s current milestone is realistic beach water: vertex-scaled waves that flatten near land and a foam layer that scrolls and fades.  Storage limits forced creative use of vertex color bits.
key_stories.challenge: Make N64-era hardware draw believable, dynamic shoreline water without exceeding memory or combiner limits.
key_stories.process: Zeroed wave height via vertex scalars near shore, devised foam texture strategy, reused red-channel bits for wave data, tested live until visual targets met.
key_stories.outcome: Prototype meets Biobak’s art direction; optimisation deferred for later.
key_stories.key_quote: We could use the lower bits of the red channel for the wave height. That might genuinely be our best option.

key_stories.title: Parallel Emulator Regression
key_stories.summary: After painstakingly coordinating with Parallel’s maintainer to fix an off-by-one memory bug, the fix failed to reach players and new bugs appeared right after release.
key_stories.challenge: Ensure RTYI demo runs on the popular Parallel emulator despite its instability.
key_stories.process: Collaborated with Falco to patch off-by-one error affecting last byte of memory; released demo; users still hit crashes because update didn’t propagate and new issues surfaced.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze resolved to avoid Parallel during development, using PJ64 despite known flaws.
key_stories.key_quote: This wouldn't have been a problem if they didn't test in production.
